title: ICAC hears Huang paid Clements over $600,000
text:
“Commissioner, I was in all sorts [of problems],” Mr Clements said of his response to the August 2015 gift.

Mr Clements stood aside as state secretary on August 7, 2015 after Labor staffer Stefanie Jones applied for an Apprehended Violence Order against him after filing a police complaint (the AVO was later dropped and no charges were laid).

He said Mr Huang telephoned him that weekend.

“I got a call to come to his home,” Mr Clements said. “I went to his house, he led me upstairs to a room I’d never been before. And he handed me a wooden wine box.

“I opened it up and inside there was money and a piece of paper that said it was for my legal costs.

“He closed the box, screwed up the paper and we walked downstairs.”

'I didn't want to explain it to her'

Mr Clements became teary-eyed as he described his reaction: “I had a lot going on. I was about to be interviewed by the police. I believed I was about to lose my job. I had had to confess to my wife to having an affair.”

Advertisement

Downstairs, “we sat there and had a chat”, he said. "And Mr Huang talked to me about being concerned for me, and that everything was going to be OK.”

Mr Clements counted the money in the car – $100 bills in seven packets of $5000.

He never banked the money: “I had a joint bank account with my wife and I didn’t, given the amount of strife I was in, want to explain it to her.”

He kept the $35,000 in a cupboard at home for more than six months, using it over time to pay part of his legal bills, he said,

Two months earlier, at the end of May 2015, he had asked Mr Huang to provide $10,000 to fund a union election campaign, where a right-wing union was facing a challenge.

Several days later, Mr Huang’s personal assistant had come to his office and handed Mr Clements a white A4 envelope.

According to his evidence, Mr Clements earned more than $600,000 from Mr Huang’s companies after he was hired as a consultant on a retainer of $4000 a week, days after he resigned as state secretary in mid-January 2016.

Advertisement

ICAC Chief Commissioner Peter Hall asked how the level of $4000 was set by Mr Huang.

“That’s what I suggested,” Mr Clements said. “He ultimately agreed.”

He said Mr Huang contacted him via a WhatsApp message on July 19, 2017 and asked to see him.

According to Clements' evidence, Mr Huang told him the Electoral Commission was inquiring into a Chinese Friends of Labor fundraiser, and that a Labor staffer, Kenrick Cheah, had said that Mr Huang had handed $100,000 to Mr Clements in an “Audi bag”.

“Why the fuck would Kenrick say that?” Mr Clements said he asked Mr Huang.

“I don’t know,” Mr Huang told Mr Clements, he said. “I left the dinner early. I don’t know who took the money home from the dinner.”
description: Ex-NSW Labor secretary Jamie Clements battled tears as he revealed a Chinese billionaire paid him over $600,000 in fees and gave him $35,000 for his legal costs.
